iati-activity.description: Improved Management Effectiveness of the Chobe- Kwando Linyanti Matrix of Protected areas for: -national policies and institutions to promote and support the participation and beneficiation of communities in natural resource management

Improved Management Effectiveness of CKL of PAs
Improved Management Effectiveness of CKL of PAs

iati-activity.title: Improved Management Effectiven
iati-activity.description: Improved Management Effectiveness of the Chobe- Kwando Linyanti Matrix of Protected areas

transaction.disbursement-channel: Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account

result.title: Objective
result.description: To strengthen management effectiveness of the Chobe-Kwando-Linyanti Matrix of PAs to respond to existing and emerging threats

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
PA budgets secure
PA management indicators including status of LE, habitats and wildlife populations

target.comment:
PA budgets of P15m cover operational costs for 14,000km2 and used effectively according to activity-based budgets and stakeholder review
14,776km2 PA (CNP10,600 km, FRs 4,176 km2) and 11,149km2 buffer zones (8,998km2 CHAs, 2,151 km2 occupied State Lands) have measurable resource protection, habitat and wildlife monitoring and PA management indicators (detailed below) are monitored and improving (i.e. habitats and wildlife, poaching, fire, problem animals, tourism, stakeholder and tourist satisfaction)

actual.comment: Activities planned for Year 2

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Community benefits and participation
HH income, especially in poor areas

baseline.comment:
P6m to committee P750,000 to villages
0 HH benefit

target.comment: 15% increase in HH income in CBNRM areas

actual.comment:
Hunting Ban in Botswana has affected the income generation of the Community Based Organizations for CBNRM, but the project has engaged in assisting communities to build sustainable rural livelihoods that will reduce poverty and dependency on natural resources. Those activities include:
- introduction of conservation farming.
- upgrading of the Chobe Enclave Conservation Trust's milling and brick molding projects so that they create more jobs for the communities.
- supporting the Chobe Fresh and Dry Fish Association.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Reduced land use and wildlife conflicts

target.comment: 2-3 lions HWC

actual.comment: Awareness creation on HWC through community meetings (traditional kgotla set up system) held in seven (7) villages in the project area. The discussions on HWC were centered on the establishment and support of human wildlife co-existence programmes, like promoting sustainable rural livelihoods options that are suitable for HWC prone area like Chobe District.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Wildlife corridors

baseline.comment: Wildlife Corridors not formally identified and therefore increasing the land use conflicts between people and wildlife

target.comment: Wildlife corridors (to Hwange, Nxai Pan/Maghadghadi, Okavango, Caprivi) and key wildlife habitats (e.g. Seloko) formally identified and secured and land use conflicts reduced to 50% of current level

actual.comment: The Land Use Conflicts Identification Strategy (LUCIS) introduced to the Chobe District Land Board, Land Use Planning authorities and stakeholders and has been accepted. The LUCIS will help identify the land use conflicts and help in the formal identification of the corridors, this will assist in developing strategies for securing the corridors.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Tourism expansion and diversification in FR, CBNRM areas and CNP

target.comment: PAC in CBNRM areas reduced to 30% of current levels (through benefit sharing and management plans). Tourism activities diversified with 250-300 beds in new areas

actual.comment: The expansion strategies are delayed by the development of the Integrated Land Use Plan of the project area, i.e. the development of the management plans for the CBNRM areas, and the development of the SEA and management plans for the Forest Reserves. All these are expected to be completed by the first quarter in 2016 them the tourism initiatives could start.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Increase in Financial Sustainability Scorecard scores

actual.comment: Activities planned for 2016

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool

actual.comment: Activities planned for year 2

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Collaborative Governance in PA and Buffer Zones Increasing Economic Growth and Removing Threats

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Stakeholder committee Role clarification Procedures

baseline.comment: Plans for CNP, CECT, CH5?? and draft plans for “Kasane as the Tourism Capital of the North”

target.comment: Stakeholder forum meeting regularly, tracking progress against project indicators and ensuring timely decision-making and corrective action Roles of stakeholders agreed in strategic plan Procedures streamlined and decision made within 90 days (e.g. approval of LUP, tourism sites, adherence to ILUP, etc.) At least 3 staff trained with degrees, 15 with certificates and diplomas, and 170 through professional short course training.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Integrated plans /processes and sub-plans
Wildlife populations at landscape level
Wildlife corridors
Compatibility of land uses
Containment of threats from infrastructure placement and tourism impact

target.comment:
PA Buffer and Wildlife Dispersal Areas zoned with clear boundaries, specific regulations, standards and code of practices and ensures compatibility of land uses with overall biodiversity management goals
Wildlife populations maintained at landscape level
Wildlife corridors identified and secured and preserving wildlife movements and access to water

actual.comment: Procurement process for the consultancy firm for the development of Integrated Land Use Plan had commenced

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
Tourism investment sites and procedures
Tourism beds, income, economic impact, employment
Number of new activities introduced
Park fees
Tourism satisfaction

target.comment:
Integrated tourism development plan agreed by stakeholders to increase investment in FRs (6 camp / 120+beds), CBNRM-linked areas (8 camps/200+ beds) by Y4
Tourism turnover increases by P65-100m with new 250-300 beds and 500 new jobs
Tourism activities diversified to include walking, night drives, horse trails, bush dinners, remote camp sites, etc introduced
Park fees increase by P2.5m
At least 80% of tourists recommend Chobe to friends

actual.comment: The activities will commence after the development and approval of the SEA and management plans for the FRs and the CBNRM areas in the district.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
Amount and % of tourism fees reaching community
Employment
Uptake of wildlife management and land use zoning by communities

baseline.comment:
CECT P4m (P150,000 to each village)
KALEPA P1,5m (nil to each village)
8 lions, 10 elephant / year

target.comment:
8 Villages receiving at least P400,000 annually with 80% benefiting HH and providing at least 250 jobs
Communities employing game guards and providing MOMS and HWC reports
HWC reduced to 4 lions, 5 elephants
LU zoning, protection and business plans implemented and monitored
Livelihoods improve 15% especially for marginal people and women (surveys)
Governance tracking shows 65%+ performance and at least 30% women representation

actual.comment:
- Hunting ban has negatively affected the revenues that were accruing to the communities and there is no income from wildlife management in the CBNRM areas at the moment. The project has started to work with the CBOs to overcome the above problem by promoting activities/projects that create employment and hire more people in a regular bases (that are not seasonal).
- The project has started working with the women's group in Pandamatenga village to develop their capacities in crafts making. The project has also developed the capacity of the Fishermen’s Association by providing materials, equipment, machinery and trainings on governance and leadership, marketing, quality assurance.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Core protected areas strengthened (financial sustainability and management effectiveness) to address existing and emerging threats to biodiversity

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Sustainable financing plan

target.comment: CNP/FR legally established as business centers by Y3 and retaining P20m to manage CNP and FRs effectively

actual.comment: Commencement of activities awaiting development of the new Management Plan for CNP and the SEA and Management Plans for the FRS.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: PA revenues

target.comment: PA revenues increased by 25% from new sites in FRs and streamlined PA gate and concession fees

actual.comment: Activities awaiting development of the new management plan for CNP and the development of the SEA and management plans for the FRs which are expected to have been completed by year 2, quarter 2.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Reduction in funding gap of the targeted PAs

baseline.comment:
CNP income: P19,200,000
CNP Budget: P5,000,000
FR income: P0
FR Budget: P3,700,000

target.comment:
CNP Income: P25m
CNP Budget: P15m
FR Income: P4m
FR budget: P 10m
Strategic surplus: P4m.

actual.comment: Revising relevant literature, for example the Appraisal on Optimising Financial and Operational Management Effectiveness of Protected Areas in Botswana and others, to be able to facilitate building of a case for a reduction in funding gap for the targeted protected areas. The activities are planned for year 2.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Effective management

target.comment: Activity based budgets and performance indicators in place by Y2

actual.comment: Revising relevant literature, for example the Appraisal on Optimising Financial and Operational Management Effectiveness of Protected Areas in Botswana and others, to be able to facilitate development of the activity based budgets and performance indicators. Activities to commence in quarter4, year 1

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Management information system

target.comment: Visualized data presented to stakeholders to support evidence-based decision making, e.g. fires, LE, habitats, wildlife, CBNRM, tourism, etc.

actual.comment: Discussions with the key stakeholders, Research Unit of DWNP and other wildlife research bodies are in progress. The purpose of the discussions is to brainstorm on the possible systems and how the data that are collected by different researchers could be presented and made available for the decision-makers and the public. The actual implementation is planned for year 2, quarter 1.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Tourism crowding and satisfaction

target.comment: 80% of tourists satisfied with game viewing along Chobe River frontage

actual.comment: Data collection tools to be developed in Quarter 3 with thee relevant authorities, after the initial results of the Chobe River Frontage Decongestion Strategy which is being implemented by MWET. The results of the survey will inform the relevant authorities on measures to be put in place to ensure that tourists are satisfied with game viewing along the Chobe River frontage

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Human resource capacity (relative to KPAs)

target.comment: In Y1, review staff numbers and capacity relative to KPAs, including job descriptions and performance criteria, and initiate a staff development plan. At least 3 staff trained with degrees, 15 with certificates and diplomas, and 170 through professional short course training.

actual.comment:
Human resource evaluation and capacity needs assessment survey conducted in order to use the information to develop a Capacity Development Plan for the park staff. The information provided by 17 staff members who responded to the questionnaire indicated that:
- staff members are not happy with their work conditions,
- their living conditions inside the park were not conducive to carry out their day to day activities,
- they lacked the right skills for park operation and management.
As a support of the Capacity Development Plan a two day workshop for the park staff was planned in July 2015 to collect more information.

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: Housing and equipment

target.comment:
At least 50 staff houses rehabilitated with water, electricity
10 vehicles

actual.comment: Through partnership with Chobe National Park management team, 8 staff houses inside Chobe National Park and one (1) gate house at Mababe Gate have been identified for refurbishment. The tendering process led by the Department of Wildlife and National Parks is expected to commence in around August 2015 and the awarding of the tender may be in the last quarter of 2015 and the actual work may commence in the first quarter of 2016. (This is subject to the availability of a competitive bidder who meets the criteria and win the bid).

indicator.title: Indicator 9
indicator.description:
Wildlife protection
Patrol days
Area coverage
Poaching catch/effort data

target.comment:
LE Management information system in place by Y2
At least 25,000 patrol days annually
Less than 1 poaching incident / 100 patrol days
Less than 10 elephant poached annually

actual.comment: Done ground work with the Research Division of DWNP, organising for the development of MOMS for the Anti-Poaching Division of DWNP and other law enforcement agencies engaged in anti-poaching activities. The training and implementation will be in year 2, quarter 1 and 2.

indicator.title: Indicator 10
indicator.description: Status of key habitats

target.comment: Habitats stable or improving

actual.comment: Assessment of the habitats planned for quarter1, year 2.

indicator.title: Indicator 11
indicator.description: Reduced area burned annually

target.comment:
Burned area reduced to 4,000km2
Effective Community Based Fire Management Committees in place by year 1
Integrated Fire Management Strategy in place

actual.comment:
Guidelines for Community Based Fire Management Committee developed, discussed with the CBFMCs and awaiting approval by the larger stakeholders’ fire management workshop planned for quarter 3, 2015. Workshop for introduction to Advanced Fire Information System (AFIS) for fire management conducted.
Community Based Fire Management Committees in place in every villages in the project area. District Fire Management Working Group (Chobe & Ngamiland) established.
Purchasing of firefighting equipment for the CBFMC process commenced.

indicator.title: Indicator 12
indicator.description: Wildlife populations in the project area are declining, expect for elephants; in 2012 numbers stood at lechwe 19, tsessebe 393, roan 477, sable 1413

baseline.comment:
CNP=100% of carrying capacity (as per aerial survey 2010)
Elephants = 91% large mammal biomass
Mammal counts (1960s; 2012)

target.comment: Stable or increasing populations of indicator / at risk species e.g. puku, red lechwe, tsessebe, sable, roan, bushbuck, slaty egret, wattled crane

actual.comment: DWNP is currently planning an aerial survey which will count on the current number and will help the Project and DWNP to develop strategies.

indicator.title: Indicator 13
indicator.description: Aquatic environment

target.comment: Baseline survey and threat assessment conducted by Y3

actual.comment: The project team has started discussions with the CARACAL, a research NGO based in the project area to get to understand issues surrounding the aquatic environment and their findings indicate that the aquatic environment is faced with some threats. The discussions will extend to the fishermen and other stakeholders to build a case for the threat assessment survey planned for Y3

iati-activity.title: Sustainable Land Management in Ngamiland
iati-activity.description: Mainstreaming SLM in Rangeland areas of Ngamiland District landscapes for improved livelihoods

iati-activity.title: Sustainable Land Management in
iati-activity.description: SLM in Ngamiland

transaction.disbursement-channel: Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account

result.title: Objective
result.description: To mainstream SLM in rangeland areas of Ngamiland District productive landscapes for improved livelihoods

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Hectares of rangeland that are under improved management

target.comment:
1 million hectares by project end
(In addition, it is expected that project lessons can be replicated to an additional 4.5 million hectares post-project)

actual.comment: The project office has been erected, furnished and officially opened. About 90% of primary and secondary stakeholders identified in the PRODOC have been mobilized and consulted regarding their roles in the project. A project board and/or Project Steering Committee comprised of representatives of relevant local government agencies, civil society organisations and print media has been established to provide policy and governance oversight to the Project Management Unit. Moreover, a Technical Reference Group (TRG) to assist in the review of consultancy Terms of Reference and other technical outputs has also been established. Preparation of an Integrated range assessment studies to establish initial range and socio-economic condition prior to management intervention are about to be undertaken following completion of draft terms of reference.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Effective range management improves range condition and flow of ecosystem services to support livelihoods of local communities

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Area of rangeland with improved grass and herbaceous species cover

target.comment: Approx. 40% (25,600 ha) in 4 ranches rehabilitated by project end

actual.comment: Range management interventions in ranches have not as yet been implemented. Emerging from consultations with commercial farmers, many are not happy with the selection of demonstration ranches. A more transparent sampling technique for selection of demonstration ranches will have to be devised and agreed to by the farmers.Also held discussions with Eco-exist, an organisation working in Ngamiland to reduce human-elephant conflict. Their interventions could prove highly useful to commercial farmers in the project who have comlained bitterly about the negative impact elephants are having on their ranches i.e. cutting of fences.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Area of riparian woodland preserved

baseline.comment: 10,000 ha of riparian woodland lost around Lake Ngami

target.comment: 200 meter buffer zone reclaimed by project end

actual.comment: Received a special request for assistance from the Lake Ngami Conservation Trust to help with management of the Lake. Solicited and obtained expressions of interest to provide manual labour for reclamation of Lake Ngami riparian zone from the University of Botswana's Environmental Club. Commencement of reclamation activities shall await the project's procurement of equipment. The completion of our integrated range assessment study of Lake Ngami and environs will also provide further guidance on how to best manage the riparian zone.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Incidence of late dry season fires

target.comment: Frequency reduced to every three years

actual.comment: Participated in two workshops, organised by BIOCHOBE and the Department of Forestry and Range Resources, investigating the efficacy of an Advanced Fire Information Management System (AFIS). The system is designed to facilitate remote detection of fires as a means to expedite ground level assets necessary to put out the fire. It is hoped that atleast 40% of the Ngamiland district's land surface would be put under surveillance as part of the project's fire management strategy in the Tsodilo Hills area.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Extent of uncontrolled fires

target.comment: Fire-affected area reduced by 50% most of the years and by 100% in two out of the five years of the project

actual.comment: No progress as yet. This activity awaits a workshop to develop the draft Tsodilo Hills Fire Management Strategy which will be held in October 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Area affected by bush encroachment

baseline.comment: 100,000 ha affected by overgrazing and bush encroachment

target.comment: Decrease by 25% by the end of the project

actual.comment: No progress as yet pending completion of integrated range assessment of all pilot areas. The assessment studies and the emergent land use maps will guide scope and target for management interventions.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: No. of farmers practicing conservation agriculture

target.comment: 30 every other year, trained and given extension support

actual.comment: Work with farmers has not yet commenced. Instead, discussions with Pabalelo Trust (one of few non governmental organisations within Ngamiland district specializing in conservation agriculture) have been held. Discussions with more potential civil society partners on ways and means to promote CA, among other things, within the district are soon to be held.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: No. of farmers practicing in improved and effective herd management

target.comment: 30 farmers enrolled for participation in the project (20 initially and 10 more added by project end)

actual.comment: No progress as yet pending completion of integrated rangeland assessment studies which are expected to objectively guide selection of area and participating farmers. Held preliminary discussions with communal rangeland farmers association representatives.

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: Stocking rates in line with the prevailing condition of the rangeland

baseline.comment: Tbd during the range assessment studies of this project

target.comment: Tbd during the project and implemented in 4 ranches by project end

actual.comment: Following consultations with commercial farmers, it has been established that stocking rates are generally difficult to enforce as a result of the extended nature of ranch ownership i.e. ranches are co-owned by multiple members of one family who each contribute any number of cattle to the holding. Moreover, because of the unreliability of the Botswana Meat Commission in buying cattle for slaughter from farmers, livestock from communal rangelands is often deliberately led into commercial ranching zone when word of imminent sale of livestock from the latter has been intercepted. Government has since erected a protective fence between Haina Veld commercial ranches and communal areas but it is currently breached in many places due to both elephant and human vandals. These issues shall be duly considered and used in the generation of management objectives and land use plans specific to the Haina Veld area.

indicator.title: Indicator 9
indicator.description:
No. of farmers[1] with improved livelihoods
[1] Farmers are disaggregated according to gender, age group and small stock keeping

baseline.comment: Tbd during range assessments which will cover farmer livelihoods as well

target.comment: Double farm generated income of farmers involved in improved herd management and CA by project end

actual.comment: No progress yet pending completion of integrated range assessment of pilot areas.

indicator.title: Indicator 10
indicator.description: Economic returns per land unit

baseline.comment: Tbd during range assessments which will include establishment of economic returns from different land uses (ranches and communal rangelands)

target.comment: Increase returns by a quarter of the baseline every year after the 2nd year

actual.comment: Progress pending completion and implementation of management objectives as recommended by the integrated range assessment studies.

indicator.title: Indicator 11
indicator.description: Capacity of key land management institutions for SLM

target.comment: Raise to 50% and improving by the end of the project

actual.comment: Most if not all relevant land management institutions are now members of the project's Technical Reference Group a development which has set the stage for a capacity self assessment to be undertaken and a capacity building/ training plan developed therefrom.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Effective governance framework and markets provide incentives for livestock off-take and compliance with SLM

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Multi-stakeholder forum for mainstreaming SLM issues in national and regional policies, plans and strategies

baseline.comment: Existing multi-sectoral institution is limited to multiple government sectors

target.comment: Active participation from government, NGOs, water and land user groups, community trusts, community leaders, private sector by project end

actual.comment: Not yet established. However, virtually all project stakeholders have been consulted over the two first quarters of 2015. It is these same stakeholders that will comprise the forum. The forum will be established and a schedule of themes for discussion developed and at least one forum meeting facilitated.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Revenue from non-beef livestock products

target.comment: Tbd during feasibility studies for setting up a processing and marketing plant

actual.comment: No progress as yet. However, individuals and communities like those of Habu village with interest and experience in leather processing, skull painting etc have been identified and will in the near future be assisted to participate in a ground breaking workshop as a precursor to feasibility studies.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Off-take rate for cattle

baseline.comment: Tbd during range assessments under the economic section

target.comment: Tbd after range assessments

actual.comment: The Botswana Meat Commission owned Maun Abattoir is shutting down for renovations that are designed to increase offtake from about 80 cattle per day to 120 cattle per day.

iati-activity.title: SLM Makgadikgadi
iati-activity.description: Using SLM to improve the integrity of the Makgadikgadi ecosystem and to secure the livelihoods of rangeland dependent communities

document-link.title: Project Document for the Sustainable Land Management in Makgadikgadi

iati-activity.title: SLM Makgadikgadi
iati-activity.description: Mainstreaming SLM practices into livestock dependent community practices.
